member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.BooleanExplorerControls.DragDropBooleanCommandEventHandler
member.summary: This class helps a max explorer container handle the drag and drop related events The drag and drop could occur between different explorers or from explorer to max viewport.

remarks.para: Besides the "NodeCommand", user could register additional node command to be executed during drag and drop. The DragDropNodeCommandEventHandler always use the first valid node command(IsValid method return true) to respond to the drag and drop events. The sequence is first check "NodeCommand", then the additional node commands as the sequence they were registered.
If you want make sure a specific node command will be used first, set it to "NodeCommand".

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.BooleanExplorerControls.DragDropBooleanCommandEventHandler.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs an empty event handler.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.BooleanExplorerControls.DragDropBooleanCommandEventHandler.HandleNodeEvent(System.Object,ExplorerFramework.TraversalNodeEventArgs)
member.summary: Event handler any Node Event. Fires the given NodeCommand.
member.param: Data about this event containing the affected node.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.BooleanExplorerControls.DragDropBooleanCommandEventHandler.HandleDragOverNode(System.Object,ExplorerFramework.TraversalNodeActionQueryEventArgs)
member.summary: Handles the DragOver event on the ExplorerContainer that it is monitoring. Will call IsValid method on each node command and set the result in TraversalNodeDragEventArgs.DragActionIsValid to true if any IsValid method return true.
member.param: The arguments for this event. The arguments contain the current target node and property that allows this handler to indicate whether the NodeCommand is valid for this target.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.BooleanExplorerControls.DragDropBooleanCommandEventHandler.HandleBeforeDragNodes(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Handles the BeforeDragNodes event on the TreeList that it is monitoring. It gets the explorer from which the event is raised and set it to all the registered node commands.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.BooleanExplorerControls.DragDropBooleanCommandEventHandler.HandleDragEnterTreeList(System.Object,System.Windows.Forms.DragEventArgs)
member.summary: Handles the DragEnter event on the TreeList that it is monitoring. It will try to get the source explorer from which the drag and drop was raised. And update all the node commands' Explorer property accordingly.
member.param: The arguments for this event. The arguments contain the source explorer from which the drag and drop operation is first raised.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.BooleanExplorerControls.DragDropBooleanCommandEventHandler.HandleQueryContinueDrag(System.Object,System.Windows.Forms.QueryContinueDragEventArgs)
member.summary: Handles the QueryContinueDrag event on the TreeList that it is monitoring. It is used to handle drag and drop from explorer to viewport. It first check if the cursor is over any viewport of 3ds Max. Then it try to get the objects that the cursor is over. Afterwards, if dragging, it call the will check if any registered node command could handle the operation and set the cursor accordingly. If dropped, it will execute the first valid node command.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.BooleanExplorerControls.DragDropBooleanCommandEventHandler.RegisterAdditionalNodeCommand(ExplorerFramework.NodeCommand)
member.summary: Register an additional node command and update its Explorer property.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.BooleanExplorerControls.DragDropBooleanCommandEventHandler.UnregisterAdditionalNodeCommand(ExplorerFramework.NodeCommand)
member.summary: Unregister an additional node command.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.BooleanExplorerControls.DragDropBooleanCommandEventHandler.UnregisterAllAdditionalCommands
member.summary: Unregister all the additional node commands.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.BooleanExplorerControls.DragDropBooleanCommandEventHandler.CanDropOnNode(ExplorerFramework.TraversalNode)
member.summary: Decide if the drop operation can be performed or not.
member.param: The target node of the drop operation
member.returns: true if the drop operation is valid, false otherwise.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.BooleanExplorerControls.DragDropBooleanCommandEventHandler.DoDropOnNodes(ExplorerFramework.TraversalNode,ExplorerFramework.TraversalNode[])
member.summary:
Try to call each command to handle the drop operation.
If there are more than one command could handle the drop operation, one solution is to pop up a dialog to let user decide to run which command or use a hotkey combination. But for now, there is no such conflict.
member.param: The target node of the node command
If the node command will work on a group of nodes, pass them by this param.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.BooleanExplorerControls.DragDropBooleanCommandEventHandler.TryToExecuteNodeCommand(ExplorerFramework.NodeCommand,ExplorerFramework.TraversalNode,ExplorerFramework.TraversalNode[])
member.summary: Try to execute the node command.
member.param: The node command to be executed
The target node of the node command
If the node command will work on a group of nodes, pass them by this param.
member.returns: If the node command is executed, return true. false otherwise.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.MaxRepositoryItemCheckEdit
member.summary:
DOCS: The RepositoryItemCheckEdit class provides properties, methods and events appropriate to check edit controls (CheckEdit class objects). The editor's CheckEdit.Properties property should be used to access these settings. The RepositoryItemCheckEdit class enables you to control the editor's look and feel, check box alignment and display style, the availability of a third "indeterminate" state, caption text, custom images to represent editor states, the manner in which the focus rectangle is displayed, values for each check state, etc. Please refer to the CheckEdit control description for details on the functionality available when using check editors.
Override the default MaxRepositoryItemCheckEdit to customize the images.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.MaxToolStripState
member.summary: This class record the location and status of a toolstrip in its parent panel.
member.remarks: The location of a toolstrip in its parent panel cannot be precisely saved and loaded. If you save the location of a toolstrip and load it from your customized file, the location of the toolbar may not be the same location that you stored in your file. According to msdn forum, this is "as designed"! For that reason, I just save and load the visibility property of toolbars. To save and load other properties such as location and floating status, we should upgrade our program to XtraBar and XtraBarManager.

member.name: P:MaxCustomControls.MaterialExplorerControls.SelectedMaterialExplorerControl.SyncToMaterialLevel
member.summary: This property is used to determine if the selected material explorer will display the exact selected material node as the root node or display the topmost material ancestor of the selected material node as the root node. If this property is true, the topmost material ancestor will be displayed as root node. If this property is false, the current selected node of scene material explorer will be displayed as root node.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.ExplorerMenuStrip.WndProc(System.Windows.Forms.Message@)
member.summary: Override the WndProc handler, so that the WM_MOUSEACTIVATE message always activates the MenuStrip. Otherwise if the host Form is a child window (consider the case of Material Explorer as Extended Viewport), clicking the MenuStrip won't activate the Form . Also, if the host Form is a child window and it's already active, the default .NET MenuStrip returns MA_ACTIVATEANDEAT for a WM_MOUSEACTIVATE message. This prevents the message to be properly handled: clicking on menu item won't really "hit" the item. Related essay: http://blogs.msdn.com/rickbrew/archive/2006/01/09/511003.aspx

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.ISerializable
member.summary: The interface for serializable objects.
member.remarks: Customizable objects could contain other serializable objects as its members or children. For example, a form's customizationState could contain several customizationState of the controls it contains.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.ISerializable.SaveState
member.summary: This method should save all the states of an object.

remarks.para: Since an ISerializable objects could contain other ISerializable "children", when saving the states, it could call each of the "children"'s SaveState and then adds the returned ICustomizationState objects to the "CustomizationStates" list of the current ISerializable object's state object.
Client should assign a unique name for each of its child state objects. And use these unique names during LoadState to get the proper child state objects.

member.returns: An object deriving from ICustomizationState interface. If failed, null will be returned.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.ISerializable.LoadState(MaxCustomControls.ICustomizationState)
member.summary: This method should restore all the states of an object.

remarks.para: Since an ISerializable objects could contain other ISerializable "children", when loading the states, it could call each of the "children"'s LoadState and pass the corresponding CustomizationState objects in the "CustomizationStates" List.
Client should assign a unique name for each of its child state objects. And use these unique names during LoadState to get the proper child state objects.

member.param: An object deriving from ICustomizationState interface.
member.returns: Return true if the object restore its states successfully, false otherwise.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.ICustomizationState
member.summary: Interface definition for CustomizationState.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.ICustomizationState.LoadProperties(System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.String})
member.summary: Given a dictionary mapping keyNames to properties, loads the properties into this CustomizationState object.

remarks.para: It is the client's responsibility to serialize and deserialize custom properties, since the Value type in the Dictionary is a String.

member.param: A dictionary mapping keyNames to properties.
member.returns: Return true if loading successfully; otherwise false.

member.summary: Create a dictionary mapping keyNames to properties, saves the properties into this dictionary.

remarks.para: It is the client's responsibility to serialize and deserialize custom properties, since the Value type in the Dictionary is a String.

member.returns: Return a dictionary mapping keyNames to properties. If failed, return null.

member.summary: Get the index-th child state object.

member.returns: If the name is valid, return the child state. null otherwise.

member.summary: This class stores the states of a form such as size, location.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.FormCustomizationState.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor.

member.summary: List of properties that this State class serializes.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.FormCustomizationState.#cctor
member.summary: Constructor which loads up a dictionary of enum-values to property names.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.FormCustomizationState.SaveProperties
member.summary: Creates a dictionary mapping keynames to properties for the properties held by this State object.

remarks.para: Clients wishing to add properties to their own custom MaxForms should extend this class and override this method. A call to the base implementation is still required to persist the core customization properties.
It is the client's responsibility to serialize and deserialize custom properties, since the Value type in the Dictionary is a String.

member.returns: A dictionary mapping keynames to property values.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.FormCustomizationState.LoadProperties(System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.String})
member.summary: Given a dictionary mapping keyNames to properties, loads the properties into this State object.

remarks.para: KeyNames not explicitly supported by this State object are ignored.

Clients wishing to add properties to their own custom MaxForms should extend this class and override this method. A call to the base implementation is still required to persist the core customization properties.
It is the client's responsibility to serialize and deserialize custom properties, since the Value type in the Dictionary is a String.

member.param: A dictionary mapping keynames to properties.

member.summary: Constructor.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeListViewInfo.SetMaxColumnIndentDirty
member.summary: Mark the max column indent to "dirty". This function could be called when the collapse/expand state of a node gets changed or the traversal list get changed.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeListViewInfo.CalcMaxIndents
member.summary: Override the base CalcMaxIndents by first check if the max indent is already calculated. With the dirty flag we avoided duplicate calculation. This is useful becuase the time complexity of base.CalcMaxIndents() is O(n), where n is the number of nodes.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.NumericSuffixBatchHandler
member.summary: This class is used to handle properties which need to be handled specially during batch edit.
member.remarks: When trying to set a new string value to all the selected nodes' registered properties, the handler will add an increment numeric suffix to the new string value before setting each node's corresponding property value. Renaming multiple nodes in SceneExplorer is an example.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.NumericSuffixBatchHandler.HandleExplorerCellValueChanged(System.Object,MaxCustomControls.ExplorerCellValueChangedEventArgs)
member.summary: A handler of ExplorerCellValueChanged Event.

remarks.para: When batch editing all the selected nodes' registered properties, it will add an increment numeric suffix to the new string value before setting each node's property value.
To use this handler, client should create an instance of this class, register the corresponding properties and attach this method to an ExplorerControl's ExplorerCellValueChanged Event.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.NumericSuffixBatchHandler.RegisterProperty(System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor)
member.summary: Register a property which need be handled by this class during batch edit.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.SceneExplorerControls.SceneExplorerDialog
member.summary: Presents the Scene node data set as a tree-hierarchy in a modeless window.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.SceneExplorerControls.SceneExplorerDialog.#ctor(System.String,ExplorerFramework.DataFacade)
member.summary: Construct a scene explorer with a given name and datafacade.
member.remarks: Constructing with a data-facade is used for performance improvements. Since modifing the properties of explorer control is time-consuming when there are a bunch of nodes, and the time complexity of many algorithms of TreeList are O(n), where n is the number of nodes. We try to speed up the initialization process by first providing a "light" datafacade, set up tree list properties, and finally, we replace the "light" datafacade with a real "heavy" datafacade before the dialog becomes visible. This strategy can improve the performance of opening and closing scene explorer by 30% when there are 10,000 nodes.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.SceneExplorerControls.SceneExplorerTreeList.OnMouseDown(System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs)
member.summary: Overrides the MaxTreeList.OnMouseDown() method to avoid the SceneExplorerTreeList losing its focus when a text cell in the "name" column is double-clicked so that the ListDoubleClick event can be captured by the control. If it is not double-clicked, the wait-for-rename operation will be handled.
member.remarks: When user double-clicks a text cell,it will get focused for the first click and the text editor control will show up and get focused for the second click before the OnMouseDoubleClick() being invoked by the TreeList which thus loses its capture for the MouseDoubleClick event.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.SceneExplorerNodesComparer
member.summary: Overrides DevExpress's base NodesComparer to customize and optimize sorting.
member.remarks: MaxNodesComparer sorts all Strings and non-comparable objects according to Windows Explorer-style natural sorting, whereby numerical parts of a string are sorted numerically instead of lexicographically. In other words, 101 will come before 1000. Optimizes by avoiding some of the unnecessary work done by the base class. We skip Custom sorting through an event, and we omit enhanced sorting, which orders objects by their position in the original underlying list.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.MaxExplorerControls.DragDropNodeCommandEventHandler
member.summary: This class helps a max explorer container handle the drag and drop related events The drag and drop could occur between different explorers or from explorer to max viewport.

remarks.para: Besides the "NodeCommand", user could register additional node command to be executed during drag and drop. The DragDropNodeCommandEventHandler always use the first valid node command(IsValid method return true) to respond to the drag and drop events. The sequence is first check "NodeCommand", then the additional node commands as the sequence they were registered.
If you want make sure a specific node command will be used first, set it to "NodeCommand".

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxExplorerControls.DragDropNodeCommandEventHandler.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs an empty event handler.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxExplorerControls.DragDropNodeCommandEventHandler.HandleNodeEvent(System.Object,ExplorerFramework.TraversalNodeEventArgs)
member.summary: Event handler any Node Event. Fires the given NodeCommand.
member.param: Data about this event containing the affected node.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxExplorerControls.DragDropNodeCommandEventHandler.HandleDragOverNode(System.Object,ExplorerFramework.TraversalNodeActionQueryEventArgs)
member.summary: Handles the DragOver event on the ExplorerContainer that it is monitoring. Will call IsValid method on each node command and set the result in TraversalNodeDragEventArgs.DragActionIsValid to true if any IsValid method return true.
member.param: The arguments for this event. The arguments contain the current target node and property that allows this handler to indicate whether the NodeCommand is valid for this target.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxExplorerControls.DragDropNodeCommandEventHandler.HandleBeforeDragNodes(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Handles the BeforeDragNodes event on the TreeList that it is monitoring. It gets the explorer from which the event is raised and set it to all the registered node commands.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxExplorerControls.DragDropNodeCommandEventHandler.HandleDragEnterTreeList(System.Object,System.Windows.Forms.DragEventArgs)
member.summary: Handles the DragEnter event on the TreeList that it is monitoring. It will try to get the source explorer from which the drag and drop was raised. And update all the node commands' Explorer property accordingly.
member.param: The arguments for this event. The arguments contain the source explorer from which the drag and drop operation is first raised.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxExplorerControls.DragDropNodeCommandEventHandler.HandleQueryContinueDrag(System.Object,System.Windows.Forms.QueryContinueDragEventArgs)
member.summary: Handles the QueryContinueDrag event on the TreeList that it is monitoring. It is used to handle drag and drop from explorer to viewport. It first check if the cursor is over any viewport of 3ds Max. Then it try to get the objects that the cursor is over. Afterwards, if dragging, it call the will check if any registered node command could handle the operation and set the cursor accordingly. If dropped, it will execute the first valid node command.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxExplorerControls.DragDropNodeCommandEventHandler.RegisterAdditionalNodeCommand(ExplorerFramework.NodeCommand)
member.summary: Register an additional node command and update its Explorer property.

member.summary: Unregister an additional node command.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxExplorerControls.DragDropNodeCommandEventHandler.UnregisterAllAdditionalCommands
member.summary: Unregister all the additional node commands.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxExplorerControls.DragDropNodeCommandEventHandler.CanDropOnNode(ExplorerFramework.TraversalNode)
member.summary: Decide if the drop operation can be performed or not.
member.param: The target node of the drop operation
member.returns: true if the drop operation is valid, false otherwise.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxExplorerControls.DragDropNodeCommandEventHandler.DoDropOnNodes(ExplorerFramework.TraversalNode,ExplorerFramework.TraversalNode[])
member.summary:
Try to call each command to handle the drop operation.
If there are more than one command could handle the drop operation, one solution is to pop up a dialog to let user decide to run which command or use a hotkey combination. But for now, there is no such conflict.
member.param: The target node of the node command
If the node command will work on a group of nodes, pass them by this param.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxExplorerControls.DragDropNodeCommandEventHandler.TryToExecuteNodeCommand(ExplorerFramework.NodeCommand,ExplorerFramework.TraversalNode,ExplorerFramework.TraversalNode[])
member.summary: Try to execute the node command.
member.param: The node command to be executed
The target node of the node command
If the node command will work on a group of nodes, pass them by this param.
member.returns: If the node command is executed, return true. false otherwise.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxToolStrip.WndProc(System.Windows.Forms.Message@)
member.summary: Override the WndProc handler, so that the WM_MOUSEACTIVATE message always activates the ToolStrip. Otherwise if the host Form is a child window (consider the case of Material Explorer as Extended Viewport), clicking the ToolStrip won't activate the Form . Also, if the host Form is a child window and it's already active, the default .NET ToolStrip returns MA_ACTIVATEANDEAT for a WM_MOUSEACTIVATE message. This prevents the message to be properly handled: clicking on toolbar button won't really "hit" the button. Related essay: http://blogs.msdn.com/rickbrew/archive/2006/01/09/511003.aspx

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeListColumn
member.summary: Specializes TreeListColumn to optimize sizing.

remarks.para: Max uses BestFit and BestWidth to try to intelligently assign column widths in a MaxTreeList. Primarily, to keep the hierarchy clear, we would like to avoid cutting off text in the first column. Unfortunately, performance is inadequate for large data sets. The base class recalculates the best width for each cell upon each call to BestFit. The base implementation further degrades performance by visiting every node in the data set to compute the max indent width for child nodes. The resulting time complexity for every call to BestFit is O(n^2), where n is the number of nodes.

To improve performance, we have applied a few optimizations. To begin, computing the best fit width is reduced to linear time complexity. Then, to avoid recomputing the best fit width unnecessarily, we hold on to the most recently computed value. The MaxTreeList responds to display changes and DataSource events to mark this value as dirty and the MaxTreeListColumn recompute it the next time the best fit width is needed.

member.summary: Overrides a lot of the DevExpress standard behaviour with custom behaviour.
member.remarks: The DevExpress.TreeList class allows the client to supply its own handling class to override the behaviour in specific situations. We take advantage of this fact. The DevExpress TreeListHandler handles mouse operations for the TreeList using a set of TreeListState classes. This MaxTreeListHandler overrides TreeListHandler to supply custom states adjusting interaction to our specifications.

member.summary: Determines whether the node's drag area has been hit.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeListHandler.MaxNodePressedState.ChangeSelection(DevExpress.XtraTreeList.ViewInfo.RowInfo)
member.summary: Overridden to make the shift-click behaviour more consistent with that of Windows.
member.remarks: The default implementation does not handle shift-click consistently with the rest of windows. If you click, then shift-click, it selects the range as expected. Then, if you shift-click again, it selects the range from the previous click to the current one. Windows handles this by selecting the range between the original click and this last click.
member.param: Descriptor for the currently hit row.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeListHandler.MaxNodePressedState.MouseMultiSelect(DevExpress.XtraTreeList.Nodes.TreeListNode,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Replaces the MouseMultiSelect method in the base class to implement selection behaviour consistent with windows explorer.
member.param: Was the pressed node the original focused node?
member.returns: true if the selection has changed

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeListHandler.MaxNodePressedState.PositionChanged
member.summary: Overridden to avoid changing the node selection when the focused node changes.
member.remarks: The default implementation changes the selection. We really don't want that. We handle selection ourselves.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.CuiUpdatable
member.summary: Receives notifications for application Custom User Interface (CUI) changes or updates.
member.remarks: Any component or client interested in being notified of any changes in the application CUI system should implement this interface. This mechanism works with MaxForm through reflection - the MaxForm acts as the observer to the change and recursively traverses all child components in its Control containers and calls UpdateColors() on any component that implements CuiUpdatable.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.CuiUpdatable.UpdateColors
member.summary: Called when a change or update has occurred in the application CUI system.
member.remarks: Clients implementing this interface should dynamically query the CUI system to acquire the new UI colors it should be using at the time of this method invocation.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.ExplorerControl
member.summary: Base UI View component for representing a tree-structure hierarchy of TraversalNodes.

remarks.para: More specific views can be created for particular data sets by extending this class to included specialized handling. The Scene Explorer expresses one such instance, where this Control is specialized for the scene node data set.

The Explorer framework has been designed to handle more generic situations, however, and as such this Explorer can be used to represent any kind of hierarchy that a third-party client might wish to represent. The ExplorerControl class provides the following functionality:
A tree-list or flat-list view of a hierarchy of nodes.
The capability to add editable Properties to these nodes that are represented as additional, sortable columns in the tree-list.
Basic and Advanced Search capabilities. Basic search is provided by a Find input TextBox at the top of the control and performs a search (either strict, wildcard-based or regular expression-based) on the TraversalNode list of the tree-list. Advanced Search is a separate component which can be added to the Explorer dialog (either as a button or a menu item) which interacts with the DataFacade associated with the ExplorerControl.
A standard set of user interface mechanisms that provides a unified workflow for Explorer implementations. This includes node drag-and-drop functionality, node filters, selection options (such as Select Children, etc), and mouse / keyboard input interactions (drag select, hotkeys, selection focus on find, and other smaller details.) As much as possible, the View has been separated from the Model so that a common approach to hierarchy browsing can be applied to a wide-range of hierarchies.

By default, the control consists of a central tree-list view, and a toolbar of controls, including a Find field, an Explorer Instance combo-box (for dynamically naming and swapping explorers) buttons to Select All, None or Invert the current selection, and a button to lock editing of cells in the Explorer.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.ExplorerControl.GetSelectedNodeCount(System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets the number of nodes being held by the internal TreeList control.
member.param: Whether to only count selected nodes wrapping max scene nodes
Whether not to count selected nodes wrapping max scene nodes that are scene xref nodes
Whether not to count selected nodes wrapping max scene nodes that are RootNodes
member.remarks: If called with onlyMaxNodes=true or excludeSceneXRefNodes=true or excludeRootNodes=true, this needs to examine all nodes, so it may be expensive.
member.returns: The number of nodes (hidden or visible) held by this control.
member.remarks: WARNING: detects nodes by casting TraversalNode to INodeTraversalNodeBase. But INodeTraversalNodeBase is used only by scene explorer, it is not used by Crease Explorer or Material Explorer. See MAXX-21122

member.remarks: WARNING: detects nodes by casting TraversalNode to INodeTraversalNodeBase. But INodeTraversalNodeBase is used only by scene explorer, it is not used by Crease Explorer or Material Explorer. See MAXX-21122

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.ExplorerCustomizationState
member.summary: A State class that represents the customization state of an explorer form.
member.remarks: This is the underlying Model object used to persist and serialize the customization state of an Explorer form. Clients can derive from this class to add their own customization properties.

member.name: P:MaxCustomControls.ExplorerCustomizationState.AutoExpand
member.summary: Controls Auto-expand behaviour on selection change. Auto-expand means a selected node gets visible when selected (by scrolling, and expanding its parents) but hidden when deselected, unless its parent had been manually expanded. Otherwise selecting a node in the scene has no effect on any Explorer node expanded state

member.summary: Internal method to check if a string corresponds to a property key we support.

member.returns: If this corresponds to a property key we support.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.ExplorerCustomizationState.LoadProperties(System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.String})
member.summary: Given a dictionary mapping keyNames to properties, loads the properties into this State object.

remarks.para: KeyNames not explicitly supported by this State object are ignored.

Clients wishing to add properties to their own custom Explorers should extend this class and override this method. A call to the base implementation is still required to persist the core customization properties.
It is the client's responsibility to serialize and deserialize custom properties, since the Value type in the Dictionary is a String.

member.param: A dictionary mapping keynames to properties.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.ExplorerCustomizationState.SaveProperties
member.summary: Creates a dictionary mapping keynames to properties for the properties held by this State object.

remarks.para: Clients wishing to add properties to their own custom Explorers should extend this class and override this method. A call to the base implementation is still required to persist the core customization properties.
It is the client's responsibility to serialize and deserialize custom properties, since the Value type in the Dictionary is a String.

member.returns: A dictionary mapping keynames to property values.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.MaxCuiBinder
member.summary: This manager is responsible for notifying interested parties of any changes in the application Custom User Interface (CUI) system settings.
member.remarks: Client components wishing to receive notification of CUI changes should implement the CuiUpdatable interface and register via the RegisterForNotification() method. This manager is a Singleton and can be accessed using the MaxCuiBinder.GetInstance() method.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxCuiBinder.GetInstance
member.summary: The Singleton accessor method.
member.returns: The single instance of this class.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxCuiBinder.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxCuiBinder.HandleUIUpdated(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Centralized handler for notifying CuiUpdatable clients.
member.param: The object that generated the event this method handles.
The args for this event. EventArgs.Empty by default.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxCuiBinder.HandleVisibilityChangedHandler(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: When the visibility of a control that has registered for notification changes, a CUI update is broadcast across all components. This handler takes care of that.
member.param: The object that generated the event this method handles.
The args for this event. EventArgs.Empty by default.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxCuiBinder.RegisterForNotification(MaxCustomControls.CuiUpdatable)
member.summary: Add the given CuiUpdatable component to the list of items notified of UI update events.
member.param: A component that implements the CuiUpdatable interface.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxCuiBinder.UnregisterForNotification(MaxCustomControls.CuiUpdatable)
member.summary: Remove the given CuiUpdatable component from the list of items notified of UI update events.
member.param: A component that implements the CuiUpdatable interface.

member.name: F:MaxCustomControls.MaxCuiBinder.mListOfHooks
member.summary: List of CuiUpdatable clients registered for notification.

member.name: F:MaxCustomControls.MaxCuiBinder.sInstance
member.summary: The singleton instance.

member.name: F:MaxCustomControls.MaxCuiBinder.mVisibleChangedHandler
member.summary: A common EventHandler added to each Control object which registers for notification.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.QuickRegexFindHandler
member.summary: Performs searches in an ExplorerControl as the user types the search key.
member.remarks: Supports plain text, regular expression, and wildcard searches.

member.name: F:MaxCustomControls.QuickRegexFindHandler.mFindActive

member.summary: Searches are performed in this control's data set.

member.summary: Field searched by this handler.

member.summary: Occurs when IsCaseSensitive is changed.

member.summary: Returns the text pattern source - or null if this is not the right source.

member.summary: Performs a search in the MatchedProperty values from the ExplorerControl's nodes, then sets the ExplorerControl's node selection to the search results.

member.remarks: The search is performed in a background thread to enable the user to continue typing.

member.summary: TextChanged event handler: will automatically execute a Find if user confirmation is not required.
member.param: source of the event - the pattern source

member.summary: Key Event handler: will automatically execute a Find if the key event is an Enter key.

used to check if this is an Enter key

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.QuickRegexFindHandler.HandleCtrlKeyEvent(System.Object,System.Windows.Forms.KeyEventArgs)
member.summary: Key Event handler: will prevent a Find to be execute as long a ctrl is pressed

used to check if control is press

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.QuickRegexFindHandler.GetPatternText
member.summary: Gets the current search pattern text from the pattern source.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.MaxForm
member.summary: This class is an augmented Form designed for use with the Max platform.
member.remarks: Clients planning on implementing managed dialogs in the application should make use of and derive from MaxForm instead of from Form directly. This class is aware of certain application-specific behaviour, such as Custom User Interface (CUI) changes, and supplies a mechanism for doing modeless dialogs that doesn't interfere with the application's hotkey system. In fact, the standard Form may not even receive any keyboard input when launched on top of the native application.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxForm.#ctor
member.summary: Default Constructor.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxForm.InitializeMainIcon
member.summary: Sets the main form icon based on the application icon.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxForm.UnbindFromMaxCui(System.Object,System.Windows.Forms.FormClosedEventArgs)
member.summary: Traverses the sub-controls of this MaxForm and automatically unbinds any that implement the CuiUpdatable interface from the application CUI system.
member.param: The object that generated the event this method handles.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxForm.BindToMaxCui(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Traverses the sub-controls of this MaxForm and automatically binds any that implement the CuiUpdatable interface to the application CUI system.
member.param: The object that generated the event this method handles.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxForm.GetMaxHookInterfaces
member.summary: Traverses sub-controls and accumulates all controls that implement the CuiUpdatable interface.
member.returns: A list of CuiUpdatable objects.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxForm.GetAllControls(System.Windows.Forms.Control)
member.summary: Returns all controls on the form and their descendants, including the form itself.

member.summary: Updates the form's colors according to the current CUI settings.
member.remarks: Implementation of CuiUpdatable interface.

member.summary: Displays this form modelessly sets the main application's window as the parent.

member.summary: Displays this form as a modal dialog and sets the passed in Form as the parent.
member.param: A form to be used as a parent of this modal Form
member.returns: The result of this modal interaction. The return value is the same as Form.ShowDialog(Form)

member.returns: A CustomizationState object containing MaxForm's states.

member.summary: Load the form states such as size from the "stateToLoad" object.
member.param: The object which contains the states of the form.
member.returns: Return true if load successfully, false otherwise

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxForm.CreateState
member.summary: A factory method for creating the state object that represents this form. Clients deriving from this class should override this method and return their own derived State object.
member.returns: An empty State object that is used to persist and serialize the state of this object.

member.summary: Enables application accelerators when the form is deactivated.
member.param: The object that generated the event this method handles.
The args for this event. EventArgs.Empty by default.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxForm.HandleActivate(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Disables application accelerators when the form is activated. Note that this is not called when Frame is active.
member.param: The object that generated the event this method handles.
The args for this event. EventArgs.Empty by default.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxForm.FormClosedHandler(System.Object,System.Windows.Forms.FormClosedEventArgs)
member.summary: Handles the Closed event.
member.param: The object that generated the event this method handles.
The args for this event. EventArgs.Empty by default.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxForm.ShowInFrame
member.summary: Adds a docking frame to the MAXForm that allows it to be docked to the left or to the right. This changes a lot of the standard behavior of Windows forms so use with caution. For example activate events are no longer triggered which in turn means that accelerators are no longer disabled when the form is activated.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxForm.RemoveFrame
member.summary: Removes the docking Frame around the MAXForm. The form styles will be restored and it will be parented to the 3ds Max main window, regardless of what it was parented to before.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxForm.SetFloatingPosition(System.Drawing.Point)
member.summary: Sets the position of the docking frame in screen coordinates. If the docking frame is docked, it will be set to 'floating' first.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxForm.GetFloatingPosition
member.summary: Returns the position of the floating docking frame in screen coordinates.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxForm.SetFloatingSize(System.Drawing.Size)
member.summary: Sets the size of the docking frame. This has only an effect when the docking frame is floating.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxForm.GetFloatingSize
member.summary: Returns the size of the floating docking frame.

member.name: P:MaxCustomControls.MaxForm.Frame
member.summary: This returns the docking frame object wrapping the form, or null if there is no frame

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList
member.summary: Derived version of the DevExpress TreeList control to customize some behaviour for Max's purposes.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.#cctor
member.summary: Static constructor for this class - assigns our localization class.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.ComputeBestWidthOperation
member.summary: Based on DevExpress's TreeListOperationColumnBestWidth but optimized to avoid that operation's n-squared time complexity.
member.remarks: Note that this class implements the dispose pattern to release some resources. It must be instantiated with the using pattern.

member.name: P:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.EditingEnabled
member.summary: Determines whether editing of properties is allowed on this treelist control.

member.name: E:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.EditingEnabledChanged
member.summary: Occurs when the EditingEnabled property value changes.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.OnEditingEnabledChanged(CSharpUtilities.ValueChangedEventArgs{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Raises the EditingEnabledChanged event.
member.param: An args object that contains the old and new parameters.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.DeactivateEditingEnabled
member.summary: Deactivates editing on this control until ResetEditingEnabled is called.
member.remarks: Used to temporarily deactivate editing on the treelist. Call ResetEditingEnabled() to reset editing to the last value of EditingEnabled.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.ResetEditingEnabled
member.summary: Resets editing on this control to the policy setting set through the EditingEnabled property.
member.remarks: See DeactivateEditingEnabled().

member.name: P:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.DragAndDropEnabled
member.summary: Determines if dragging and dropping TreeListNodes is enabled.

member.name: P:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.InModalSceneExplorerDialog
member.summary: Determines if displayed in a modal scene explorer dialog.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.DeactivateDragAndDrop
member.summary: Temporarily turn off drag and drop in this tree list without affecting the actual policy.
member.remarks: The behaviour as specified by the DragAndDropEnabled option can be reset later using ResetDragAndDrop.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.ResetDragAndDrop
member.summary: Reset deactivated drag and drop behaviour to the policy as set through the DragAndDropEnabled option.
member.remarks: See DeactivateDragAndDrop().

member.name: P:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.ShowRoot
member.summary: Determines whether the root node is displayed in the treelist.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.DeactivateShowRoot
member.summary: Temporarily turn off tree root display in this tree list without affecting the actual policy.
member.remarks: The behaviour as specified by the ShowRoot option can be reset later using ResetShowRoot.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.ResetShowRoot
member.summary: Reset deactivated root node display to the policy as set through the ShowRoot option.
member.remarks: See DeactivateShowRoot().

member.name: P:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.EnableEnhancedSorting
member.summary: Speeds up sorting by disabling so-called "enhanced sorting," which really just sorts by the node's index within the original list if all other sort columns come out equal.

member.name: F:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.mEditingEnabled
member.summary: Storage for the EditingEnabled property.

member.name: F:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.mDragAndDropEnabled
member.summary: Storage for the DragAndDropEnabled property.

member.name: F:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.mShowRoot
member.summary: Storage for the ShowRoot property.

member.name: F:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.mInModalSceneExplorerDialog
member.summary: Whether displayed in a modal scene explorer dialog.

member.name: E:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.DataSourceChanged
member.summary: Occurs after the DataSource property is changed to a different value.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.UpdateDataSource(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Overridden from TreeList to fire DataSourceChanged.
member.remarks: The base TreeList does not expose a DataSource changed event and the DataSource property itself is not virtual. This method is our first opportunity to hook into the DataSource changing pipeline to add the event.
member.param: See TreeList.UpdateDataSource(bool) The parameter is passed to this base method.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.OnDataSourceChanged
member.summary: Raises the DataSourceChanged event.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.InvalidateData
member.summary: Marks the DataDirty property and calls Invalidate on TreeList.
member.remarks: This will schedule a refresh of the data set. The refresh will be performed at the beginning of the next repaint. Repaints occur after the application finishes its current processing job and control returns to the main message loop. In this way, multiple refreshes can be batched together and performed all at once, when the application is no longer busy.

member.name: P:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.UserSelectionChangedEnabled
member.summary: Controls whether the UserSelectionChanged event will fire.
member.remarks: The selection functions below automatically disable UserSelectionChanged when called.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.SetSelection(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{DevExpress.XtraTreeList.Nodes.TreeListNode})
member.summary: Sets the selection in this tree list to the passed in list of TreeListNodes.
member.remarks: Intended for programmatically changing the selection set, this method differs from manipulating the Selection list directly on the base class by disabling the UserSelectionChanged event while changing the selection.
member.param: An enumerable list of nodes to set as the selection.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.AddToSelection(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{DevExpress.XtraTreeList.Nodes.TreeListNode})
member.summary: Adds the passed in list of TreeListNodes to the selection in this tree list.
member.remarks: Intended for programmatically changing the selection set, this method differs from manipulating the Selection list directly on the base class by disabling the UserSelectionChanged event while changing the selection.
member.param: An enumerable list of nodes to add to the selection.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.AddToSelection(DevExpress.XtraTreeList.Nodes.TreeListNode)
member.summary: Adds the passed in TreeListNode to the selection in this tree list.
member.remarks: Intended for programmatically changing the selection set, this method differs from manipulating the Selection list directly on the base class by disabling the UserSelectionChanged event while changing the selection.
member.param: A node to add to the selection.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.RemoveFromSelection(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{DevExpress.XtraTreeList.Nodes.TreeListNode})
member.summary: Remove the passed in list of TreeListNodes from the selection in this tree list.
member.remarks: Intended for programmatically changing the selection set, this method differs from manipulating the Selection list directly on the base class by disabling the UserSelectionChanged event while changing the selection.
member.param: An enumerable list of nodes to remove from the selection.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.RemoveFromSelection(DevExpress.XtraTreeList.Nodes.TreeListNode)
member.summary: Remove the passed in TreeListNode from the selection in this tree list.
member.remarks: Intended for programmatically changing the selection set, this method differs from manipulating the Selection list directly on the base class by disabling the UserSelectionChanged event while changing the selection.
member.param: A node to remove from the selection.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.InvertSelection
member.summary: Inverts the current selection set.
member.remarks: If the selection set is currently empty, then all nodes are selected. If the selection set contains all nodes, then the selection is cleared. Otherwise, all nodes that are selected are removed from the selection set and vice-versa.

member.name: P:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.DataDirty
member.summary: A property which acts a dirty flag for the TreeList DataSource data.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.OnItemChanged(System.Int32)
member.summary: Overrides TreeList.OnItemChanged method.
member.remarks: Though inappropriately named for our "OnBlah fires the Blah event" convention, OnItemChanged is where the base TreeList handles an ListChanged.Item event. We override it here to simply schedule a repaint and mark the data as dirty. The default action is to immediately reevaluate everything and re-sort. Reevaluation is now deferred to paint, which batches these updates and waits until control returns to the message pump. We skip resorting altogether, allowing the user to resort by clicking the column header.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.OnPaint(System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs)
member.summary: OnPaint is overridden to handle any updating deferred earlier.
member.remarks: When a subject signals that it is dirty, the MaxTreeList just makes a note of it, schedules a repaint, and defers updating until Max is no longer busy and control returns to the main event loop.
member.param: the event args for this paint event

member.summary: Resizes the first column. When the treelist is resized horizontally, all the data columns stay the same size But the first column, with the node names will resize itself. All data columns will stick to the right of the tree list control, and the first column, the name column will resize to fill the gap.

member.name: P:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.IconSize
member.summary: The size of icon that will displayed in tree list in the left side of each node. This is set by the material explorer.

member.summary: The size of the icon that will displayed in tree list in the *left* side of each *node icon*. This is set by the material explorer.

member.name: F:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.AscendingAgeSortOrder
member.summary: The AscendingAgeSortOrder corresponds to Sort.Descending on handle columns. Lower handle values correspond to 'older' nodes.

member.name: F:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.DescendingAgeSortOrder
member.summary: The DescendingAgeSortOrder corresponds to Sort.Ascending on handle columns. Higher handle values correspond to 'newer' nodes.

member.name: P:MaxCustomControls.MaxTreeList.NameColumnSortOrder
member.summary: The last specified sort order for the name column.
member.remarks: When not explicitly sorting on name or handle column, we implicitly sort on one of them as the last sort field, using the last specified sort order. We store an 'extended' sort order in mNameColumnSortOrder, with potential values including AscendingAgeSortOrder and DescendingAgeSortOrder above. When sorting Age, we aren't sorting on the name column, rather we sort on the handle column. This makes sense from a UI perspective, but doesn't make a whole lot of sense from the code perspective. In other words, hack city!

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.ProgressDialog
member.summary: Manages executing ExplorerFramework.Commands. If an executed Command is Cancelable, this Dialog will display its progress and enable the user to Cancel the Command while preventing the user from interacting with the Max scene. Non-cancelable Commands are executed directly, halting all other application execution.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.ProgressDialog.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor.

member.name: P:MaxCustomControls.ProgressDialog.BackgroundCommandRunner
member.summary: Runs Cancelable Commands in a background thread to maintain user interactivity.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.ProgressDialog.ExecuteCancelableCommand(ExplorerFramework.Command)
member.summary: Explicitly execute the given Command as a Cancelable command. Shows this dialog to display progress and to allow the user to cancel the Command. Uses a modal form to prevent the user from modifying the scene during the Command's execution.

list.item: DialogResult.None if the Command is invalid.
DialogResult.Ok if the Command executed to completion.
DialogResult.Cancel if the user canceled the operation.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.ProgressDialog.ExecuteCommand(ExplorerFramework.Command)
member.summary: Executes the given Command, displaying the progress and cancel dialog only if the Command supports it.

remarks.para: If the given Command is Cancelable, this will create a ProgressDialog to display the Command's progress and allow the user to Cancel its execution. The ProgressDialog is modal to prevent the user from modifying the scene while the Command is running.
If the given Command is not Cancelable, no ProgressDialog is displayed. The Command is run in the main thread, stopping all other execution and disabling interactivity until the Command completes.

returns.item: DialogResult.None if the Command is invalid.
DialogResult.Ok if the Command executed to completion.
DialogResult.Cancel if the user canceled the operation.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.ExplorerContainer
member.summary: Implements some basic functionality that is both useful and required by any Form that wishes to hold an ExplorerControl component.
member.remarks: Clients wishing to implement their own Explorer forms should derive a Form class from this class. Although this class is not strictly abstract, the ExplorerControl property is meant to be overridden and will throw an exception if called with its current implementation. This class is kept concrete to faciliate usage in the Visual Studio Designer.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.ExplorerContainer.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor that attaches handlers for activating, closing the form, and handler for dealing with hotkeys.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.ExplorerContainer.HandleHotkey(System.Object,System.Windows.Forms.KeyEventArgs)
member.summary: Handler for dealing with Form hotkeys.
member.remarks: Clients can override this method to handle their own hotkeys using the same mechanism that is used in the application Scene Explorer. If the client handler doesn't handle a key event, it should call base.HandleHotkey (this method) to allow the event to "bubble up" to this more generic handler.
member.param: The arguments for this event. If the hotkey is being handled, then the Handled field should be marked as true.

member.name: P:MaxCustomControls.ExplorerContainer.ExplorerControl

member.remarks: This implementation of this property throws a NotImplementedException. Deriving classes MUST override this method and supply their own implementation.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.TextFocusHelper
member.summary: Consolidates Focus-related event handlers preventing key events from being inadvertently sent to Max.
member.remarks: To use, aggregate an instance of this class and hook up the event handlers to a text control. It is recommended that each TextFocusHelper instance manage only one control, ie. that a helper instance not be shared between multiple controls.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.TextFocusHelper.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor: creates an unbound TextFocusHelper. The event handlers must be bound manually.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.TextFocusHelper.#ctor(System.Windows.Forms.Control)
member.summary: Construct passing in a Control. The event handlers will be automatically bound to the target's GotFocus and LostFocus events.
member.param: Target control to which to bind this helper's event handlers.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.TextFocusHelper.#ctor(System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripControlHost)
member.summary: Construct passing in a ToolStripControlHost, such as a ToolStripTextBox or a ToolStripComboBox. The event handlers will be automatically bound to the target's GotFocus and LostFocus events.
member.param: Target control to which to bind this helper's event handlers.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.TextFocusHelper.BindToTarget(System.Windows.Forms.Control)
member.summary: Binds HandleGotFocus to the target's GotFocus event and HandleLostFocus to the target's LostFocus event.
member.remarks: This uses GotFocus and LostFocus instead of Enter and Leave because the lower-level GotFocus and LostFocus events are more reliably called. For example, if this object is bound to an item on a ToolStrip and the item is placed on the Overflow drop down menu, Enter and Leave are never called, but GotFocus and LostFocus are reliably called.
member.param: Target control to which to bind this helper's event handlers.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.TextFocusHelper.HandleGotFocus(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Handles GotFocus or any other event where the sender gains the keyboard focus.
member.param: source of the event - the bound control

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.TextFocusHelper.HandleLostFocus(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Handles LostFocus or any other event where the sender loses the keyboard focus.
member.param: source of the event - the bound control

member.summary: Keeps track of the current Application Accelerator on / off state

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.ToolStripPanelLocation
member.summary: Each of the enumeration value indicates a ToolStripPanel location of a ToolStripContainer.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.ToolStripContainerLayout
member.summary: This class records the layout information of all toolbars inside a given ToolStripContainer. We then use this class to arrange toolbars to their correct location in this container.

remarks.para: This is a temporary work around for ToolStrip layout. I created this class for two reasons:

1. The standard ToolStrip that provided by Microsoft has bugs and their position cannot be accurately set. I googled this and I found a lot of developers complained about this, see the link: connect.microsoft.com/VisualStudio/feedback/ViewFeedback.aspx?FeedbackID=114610

2. Replace ToolStrip with other products can solve this problem, However, doing so means completely rewrite of the icon management, the buttons on the toolbars, the container panel of the toolbars, the save and load of toolbar layout information ---- which, means the completely rewrite of the entire toolbar mechanism of both scene explorer and material explorer. We decide to do this in Zelda timeframe.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.ToolStripContainerLayout.#ctor(System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripContainer)
member.summary: Constructor.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.ToolStripContainerLayout.Clear
member.summary: Clear all layout information of this ToolStripContainer.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.ToolStripContainerLayout.AddToolStrip(MaxCustomControls.ToolStripPanelLocation,System.Int32,System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip)
member.summary: Add a ToolStrip at the given location of this ToolStripContainer.
member.param: Which panel does this ToolStrip lay?

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.ToolStripContainerLayout.SuspendLayout
member.summary: Suspend the layout of all toolstrips of this ToolStripContainer. So even the property of a toolstrip get changed, we won't perform layout.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.ToolStripContainerLayout.ResumeLayout
member.summary: Resume the layout of all toolstrips of this ToolStripContainer. Notice this function will not perform layout. You need to explicitly call PerformLayout.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.ToolStripContainerLayout.PerformLayout
member.summary: Perform the layout of all toolstrips of this container.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.ToolStripPanelLayout
member.summary: Records and perform the layout of all toolbars in a ToolStripPanel. A ToolStripPanel may has several rows, each row contains a set of ToolStrips.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.ToolStripRowLayout
member.summary: Records and perform the layout of all toolbars in a row of a ToolStripPanel.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.ExplorerNodesComparer
member.summary: Overrides DevExpress's base NodesComparer to customize and optimize sorting.
member.remarks: MaxNodesComparer sorts all Strings and non-comparable objects according to Windows Explorer-style natural sorting, whereby numerical parts of a string are sorted numerically instead of lexicographically. In other words, 101 will come before 1000. Optimizes by avoiding some of the unnecessary work done by the base class. We skip Custom sorting through an event, and we omit enhanced sorting, which orders objects by their position in the original underlying list.

member.name: T:MaxCustomControls.UIOptions
member.summary: Static options used to configure this library in general.

member.name: P:MaxCustomControls.UIOptions.LaunchedFromMax
member.summary: Indicates if this library is loaded in Max and needs its specialized handling.
member.remarks: In an effort to make this library not-Max specific, this property has been added to allow client code to dynamically check whether it is running in the context of a Max session. The underlying assumption also is that if this value is true, then IsDesignerMode is false.

member.name: P:MaxCustomControls.UIOptions.IsDesignerMode
member.summary: Indicates if this library is loaded in the Visual Studio designer.
member.remarks: This is a mechanism that client code can use to determine whether the code being run is done in the context of a running application, or in the context of the Visual Studio (or other IDE) designer. Sometimes it is useful and necessary to exclude certain calls based on whether the code is being run by the designer or not.

member.name: M:MaxCustomControls.UIOptions.InitializeForMax
member.summary: Initializes Max-specific constants and hooks up the specialized ToolStrip renderer. (Reserved for use in Max.)

member.summary: Storage for LaunchedFromMax

member.name: F:MaxCustomControls.UIOptions.sIsDesignerMode
member.summary: Storage for IsDesignerMode
